title: Are the Japanese the most narcissistic society? - Quora

response.answer_text: No less an authority than Wikipedia would tell us that narcissism is “the pursuit of gratification from vanity or egotistic admiration of one's own attributes.” So we’re concerned here with whether the Japanese are vain or self-centered in the way they prize their own national qualities or character, and whether or not they pursue gratification from these less-than-realistic attitudes. Clearly, Mr Hattori Takeshi (in the linked article above) is narcissistic. So is he representative of Japan? Every country takes pride in its own achievements, and every government has a stake in promoting this pride. Can you imagine watching the evening news in country X, and hearing a national leader express shame, regret or opposition to everything that was reported for that broadcast? So there’s a bit of vanity, at least some admiration of one’s own country, no matter where you find yourself. Whether this is realistic or not depends on how far you accept the opinions of others in that country about the quality and quantity of those achievements. When we drop postage stamp countries like Luxembourg and San Marino, Japan’s GDP per capita is among the 20 best in the world, and this without significant energy or mineral resources. Like Scandinavia, Japan has built a national economy based on adding value to its people, and there’s much to be admired for that reason. Much of that building happened before WWII, otherwise there would never have been any collision with other colonial powers. So at least some of Mr Hattori’s comments are not anachronistic. But does Japan go overboard in its own self-estimation? Overall economic performance regularly places Japan on par with Germany, Canada, the U.K., Italy and France- no one can argue can these results. And if you agree with some talking heads, that this Japan is at the end of a decade or two of an economic “slump,” you only reinforce the Japanese’ own reason for pride in their national standings. We could go through other categories of national achievements since WWII: sports, art, literature, Nobel Prizes and other international awards, music, and so on, but the results will be the same. Japan compares extremely well with many countries, sometimes near the top. So unrealistic gratification from overestimating its own accomplishments is no more found in Japan than in any other country. You can debate whether narcissism in Japan is isolated or pervasive, passive aggressive or openly expressed. But you cannot debate whether Japan has the most narcissistic society in the world, not when many countries have reason to envy Japan’s national record.

No, that’s England. There’s a difference. Japanese in general don’t see themselves as a great world power. They see themselves as a uniquely unique and special place that is fundamentally different (read better) than other countries. In contrast, the English think they are a great, no, THE greatest world dominant superpower that together with their American ‘’allies’’ control the planet. Their delusionism is so abysmal, that even Angela Merkel, the leader of Germany said that quote: ‘’Some English politicians live on a parallel universe’’. I’m not going to go into details, but if you look at what many English politicians, including members of their media says, you’re not going to believe these people are actually for real. Probably one of my favorite characters is Daniel Hannan who wrote a book claiming Britain invented ‘’Freedom’’. Another character is Boris Johnson who said that, quote: ‘’Our foreign policy is to have our cake and eat it too’’. In reality, anyone who doesn’t have a cabbage for a brain would see that England is just an American ポチ with a massive, ultra massive superiority complex who have came to the painful realization that the only way for them to remain remotely relevant on the world stage is to glue themselves to America and pretend they are a ‘’team’’.  The truth is that everyone wants their country to be ‘’special’’, but at the same time, most educated people realize that their country is not special, but some people just refuse to succumb to reality, and take their delusions to a whole another level. It’s called delusions of grandeur, there’s no known cure for that.

Like many things in Japan, this one’s all over the map. Some people love Japan, and they will tell you how everything from the water to manners are just better in Japan. They sometimes have really interesting reasons. The way the water gets filtered through the ground, for example, means that water in Japan is more pure. There are others who are a bit down on Japan. The are apologetic about Japan’s role in WWII, the stagnant economy, and how crowded it is in Japan. The majority of Japanese have no opinion.
